abstract.p: Item explains how Connecticut coastline was formed and impact past hurricanes have had in shifting shoreline (S)

block.p: A fortuitous accident of geology shaped the coastline of Connecticut into a chockablock mixture of bed-rock (glacial debris made of gneiss and granite) and drift (gravel, sand, silt and clay). About 22,000 years ago, when the Wisconsin glacier covered much of what is now Connecticut's shoreline, it extended 115 miles beyond the south shore of Long Island. Ah, those were the days.
Even as recently as 1938, 1955 and 1985, when hurricanes hit the coast, the sand along the shoreline has been redistributed in new, not always pleasant, patterns.

A fortuitous accident of geology shaped the coastline of Connecticut into a chockablock mixture of bed-rock (glacial debris made of gneiss and granite) and drift (gravel, sand, silt and clay). About 22,000 years ago, when the Wisconsin glacier covered much of what is now Connecticut's shoreline, it extended 115 miles beyond the south shore of Long Island. Ah, those were the days.
Even as recently as 1938, 1955 and 1985, when hurricanes hit the coast, the sand along the shoreline has been redistributed in new, not always pleasant, patterns.

In ''A Moveable Shore: The Fate of the Connecticut Coast'' (Duke University Press), Peter Charles Patton and James M. Kent call the September 1938 hurricane ''the most catastrophic natural even in modern Connecticut history . . . changes it made in the Connecticut coast persist to this day.''

The richest deposits of sand in the state today lie in a coastal plain, between Guilford Point and Hatchett Point in Old Lyme. Not surprisingly, the 175,000 gallons-per-second outflow of the Connecticut River is the source of most of this sand.
